 FOREWORD This paper is one in a special series of World Bank Staff Working Papers on population change and development. Prepared as background papers for the World Development Report 1984, they provide more detailed treatment and documentation of the issues dealt with in Part II of the Report. The papers cover a range of topics, including the effects of population growth and change on economic development, the determinants of fertility and mortality, the links between population growth and internal and international migration, and the management, financing, and effectiveness of family planning programs. They include several country and regional studies of fertility change and population policy. The background papers draw on a large number of published and unpublished studies of individual researchers, on Bank policy analysis and research, and on reports of other organizations working on population and development programs and issues. The papers are the work of individuals and the views and interpretations expressed in them do not necessarily coincide with the views and interpretations of the Report itself. I hope these detailed studies will supplement the World Development Report 1984 in furthering understanding of population and development issues among students and practitioners of development. Nancy Birdsall Staff Director World Development Report 1984

 Abstract This paper traces the sources of assistance for family planning and other "population" programs from developed countries and the flow of assistance through principal "channel" organizations to developing countries. Official development assistance for population comes primarily from the United States, the Nordic countries, and more recently from the Federal Republic of Germany and Japan. Population assistance is channeled mainly through the United Nations Fund for Population Assistance (UNFPA), non-governmental organizations, bilateral programs, and the World Bank. The paper discusses why developing countries seek and why developed countries offer population assistance, focusing on official views of how population growth and high fertility affect economic development, environment, maternal and child health, and women's welfare. It explains why some countries are reluctant to seek or provide more population assistance. It analyzes what population assistance does to extend reliable and affordable family planning services and information and to improve understanding of population growth, its causes, and consequences. It summarizes current population policies and family planning programs in major regions of the third world and discusses the role of assistance. The paper brings out comparative advantages of principal organizations providing population assistance, focusing on UNFPA, the major non-government organizations, and the major bilateral programs. Finally, the paper discusses the evolution of "policy issues" affecting population assistance, especially donors' concern for "demand" for family planning, cost-efffectiveness of family planning services, safety, and voluntarism. It notes efforts to assess the future need for population assistance. Acknowledgment My thanks to several organizations for sharing thoughts and previously unpublished information so readily. UNFPA, the International Planned Parenthood Federation, Family Planning International Assistance, the Pathfinder Fund, the Population Council, U.S. Agency for International Development, and Swedish International Development Authority were particularly helpful. Thanks also to my colleagues in the Bank, especially in PHN but also Nancy Birdsall, Paul Isenman and Alex Shakow, for help with earlier drafts. Responsibility for remaining shortcomings is, of course, mine.

 Summary and Conclusions 1. Where does "population assistance" for developing countries come from? Where does it go, and through what organizations? Why is it given and why sought? What does it accomplish? 2. This paper traces the flow of population assistance from donor governments through major "channel" organizations to developing countries.l/ "Population assistance" for family planning and other "population programs" accounts for less than two percent of all official development assistance provided by governments--about $370 million annually now (over 90% grants). It comes primarily from the United States, the Nordic countries, Japan and the Federal Republic of Germany. Beyond this the World Bank lends for population and related health services.Z/ This paper focuses on official population assistance from governments and covers Bank lending only as it affects this assistance. 3. Official population assistance goes through three main channels: (1) the United Nations Fund for Population Activities and other U.N. agencies, (2) non-governmental organizations, notably the worldwide network of national family planning associations loosely tied together through the International Planned Parenthood Federation, and (3) bilateral programs, primarily that of the United States. The World Bank is the major additional channel. Population assistance goes to widely distributed countries in all three major continents of the third world. While most donors and channels try to give priority to poorer countries and regions, opportunities there may be limited, and allocations thus reflect opportunities as well as "need." 4. Donors and recipients of aid are driven to contribute and request population assistance from four principal rationales, differentially weighed and accepted by different sources of political support. Most readily accepted is a maternal and child health rationale, based on what family planning can do for the health and well-being of children and their mothers. Related to this is a women's opportunity rationale. Increasingly widely accepted and espoused is a development rationale, based on the burden population growth imposes on efforts to raise living standards. Most controversial is a growth-limits rationale, based on the asserted danger that continued population growth will overwhelm the environment of individual countries or of the earth itself. 5. Indeed, po central are these rationales, that some explanation is required to account for the minute share of development assistance that has gone to population programs. The explanation lies partly in incomplete 1/ Assistance as defined by the United Nations. Separating assistance "for population" from that "for health" is difficult. 2/ Total Official Development Assistance as defined by the Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) also includes governments' contributions of capital to the World Bank. But "official population assistance" is defined as ODA provided by governments specifically to address population and excludes Bank lending for population.

In the Near East, cultural traditions affecting women and economic conditions still often yield pronatalist attitudes, but several countries (e.g., Egypt and Tunisia) are committed to family planning and are trying to extend services. 14. Population programs have involved unusually close cooperation between assistance organizations and developing-country governments, family planning organizations, and other local groups to: -- bring reliable, affordable and acceptable family planning services and information within closer reach of people even in rural areas; -- increase research to improve family planning methods and ways of delivering services; -- improve understanding of demographic trends and their causes and consequences. Developing countries as a whole now contribute more to their own population and family planning programs than they receive in assistance. Assistance organizations nonetheless remain critical sources of funding, technical advice and logistical support. Continuity of such assistance (policy, funding levels, mechanisms) is key to smooth operation of programs. UNFPA 15. UNFPA is the principal channel for population assistance to governments particularly for the poorer countries of Asia and Africa. UNFPA typically assists in establishing population policies and family planning services and information programs (often along with maternal and child health services). It supports research and demographics too. Its annual program of roughly $130 million (all grants) exceeds one-third of official population assistance. It is supported by over 90 countries. The United States provides about one-fourth of UNFPA's income. IPPF 16. The national family planning associations of IPPF typically initiate family planning service delivery, to show that services will indeed be used. They press governments to extend family planning and to adopt supportive policies. As governments do extend family planning, the associations shift focus toward hard-to-reach groups or new kinds of services. (Sometimes--e.g. Colombia and recently in Africa--governments ask the associations to help extend family planning.) The associations provide critical continuity even during political upheaval and often set standards for cost-effectiveness. They now spend about $90 million annually, over half from official development assistance from some 25 nations. UNFPA and other organizations add modest amounts. Other Private Channels 17. Where development has generated economic and social conditions conducive to smaller families and to effective program management, family planning services are often welcomed and fertility falls rapidly (e.g., Mexico and Colombia). "Outreach" is particularly effective. 27. Even where poverty persists, services offering safe and effective contraceptives conveniently and with sensitivity to culture do appeal, as in Indonesia and Thailand. Here too community-based "outreach" (in conjunction with some development progress) seems key. Outreach is also promising in less conducive settings, including Bangladesh and India. In Africa and the Near East, extending services may be still more difficult. Nonetheless, services have impact even when demand is limited by poverty and culture if they provide several family planning methods and information on appropriate use through community-based outreach. 28. Most donors consider such family planning programs attractive on cost grounds. Establishing basic health services including family planning now costs roughly $5-20 per capita population. (Family planning alone accounts for perhaps 25% of this.) The average cost per active user of family planning alone seems to fall within twenty dollars. (Marginal costs tend to be higher in early stages, thin fall until existing demand is more or less satisfied, when they may rise--though this varies.) Most family planning costs recur (salaries, contraceptives), and many are "local". While donors and channels help cover such costs, their willingness may erode as requests for population assistance increase--and as demand grows for broader health care. 29. Donors remain concerned, however, that family planning programs be voluntary, safe, and culturally attuned. Several donors encourage that family planning be provided with broader maternal and child health services, to improve the appeal and the quality of family planning services. As determining appropriate balance among services is difficult when health-care budgets are tight and health care is scarce, support for more focused family planning programs also exists. Substantial research has been funded to improve contraceptive technology and to improve delivery of family planning services, often in conjunction with broader health care. 30. If donors believe population assistance is wanted, if they believe no one else will step in to help, and if they believe population assistance works reasonably well, then they may be more willing to increase it beyond the current 1-2% of ODA. Rising requests for population assistance throughout the third world and the growing evidence of its effectiveness have helped sustain population assistance. Donors are aware that less than 40% of couples in the third-world outside China now have reasonable regular access to reliable and affordable family planning. This level of service costs somewhat over $1 billion--roughly $500 million from assistance--and is associated with an average birth rate of about 37. But future assistance is hard to predict given "aid fatigue" and controversy surrounding population assistance particularly in the United States. 31. This paper is intended to serve as a reference on "population assistance" and is organized into sections covering particular donors, channel organizations, etc.

Sources of Assistance for Population 1.01 In 1981, (the latest available year) Official Development Assistance from governments for population reached about $374 million, almost all from the 17 countries of the OECD's Development Assistance Committee (DAC). This is about 1.5% of total DAC Official Development Assistance of about $26 billion. Population assistance has never accounted for more than about 2% of DAC ODA. Beyond this, the World Bank provides some population assistance. The U.S. Ford and Rockefeller Foundations also provide some resources for population but receive no ODA. As Table 1.1 shows, total population assistance froa DAC ODA, the World Bank, the two foundations, and other minor sources reached some $491 million in 1981. This study focuses on the portion that government provide, about three-fourths of the total. 1.02 The United States is by far the leading donor, providing over half--about $193 million in 1981 (on expenditure basis) and $211 million in 1982 (on a commitment basis). Japan, Norway and Sweden provided over $30 million; Germany ranked next at $23 million. The Nordic countries are traditionally leading supporters of population assistance and together provided almost $75 million in 1981. Japan and Germany have become major supporters recently. (See Chart 1.1.)  1.04 While U.S. assistance climbed, other donors' assistance climbed faster, so that the U.S. share gradually declined to roughly 40%. Japan's assistance rose dramatically (from $2.1 million in 1971 to $33.4 million in 1981 and a reported $42.6 million in 1982). The Nordic countries, Canada, West Germany, and the Netherlands all increased their commitments as well. Most recently, however, assistance from the United Kingdom, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, West Germany, and other donors declined somewhat in dollar terms. (This partly reflects adjustments in exchange rates as the dollar gained strength.) 1.05 Population assistance has lost ground to other forms of develop- ment assistance which have outpaced its growth. "Level of effort", meaning the fraction of ODA devoted to population assistance, declined erratically from about 2% in the early 1970's to only 1.3% in 1980, 1.45% in 1981. (See Chart 1.4.) Norway traditionally leads in level of effort, with a high of about 11% in 1976, but declined to about 6.9% in 1981. (See Chart 1.5.) Sweden traditionally ranks second, with a high of 6.4%, but slipped to about 3.4% recently. The United States--the major donor--traditionally ranks third at 2-4% and is at 3.4% recently. Despite Japan's increases, its population assistance still constitutes only 1% of its ODA, which has also risen rapidly. Germany's level of effort has fluctuated and recently is about .7%. The United Kingdom has maintained about 1% until 1981 when it fell to .6%. On balance, some traditional leading donors have slipped in "level of effort," and others have only partly compensated.

 - 15 - 1.09 The major multilateral channel for official population assistance is the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA). Germany, Japan and the Netherlands contribute most of their population assistance through UNFPA, and most others except the United States contribute at least one third. The United States is nonetheless UNFPA's leading donor, contributing about one-sixth of its population assistance to cover about one-fourth of UNFPA's program. UNFPA's other leading donors include the Nordic countries, Germany and Japan, though some 90 nations each contribute something. Recently UNFPA's annual budget has averaged roughly $130 million. It operates in some 127 countries in every region of the world. UNFPA is a politically acceptable source to all countries. It is flexible in what it will fund and makes grants rather than loans. It can assist in a variety of population-related fields, such as primary health care that includes family planning, public information, demography and census-taking, and policy development, though it spends about two-fifths of its program funds on family planning and related health services. It devotes about two-thirds of its resources to some 53 priority" countries (based primarily on need). It often uses other U.N. agencies, including WHO and UNICEF, as "executing agencies" for projects it funds, though some governments act as their own executing agencies (and sometimes involve local private organizations). 1.10 WHO, UNICEF, and other U.N. agencies -- FAO, ILO, UNESCO -- are increasingly engaged in population-related activities, often through linkages with UNFPA, but sometimes using their own resources. But while many other U.N. organizations may fund activities that bear in some way on population, UNFPA has the most direct impact. Unless otherwise noted, this study treats UNFPA as the U.N. channel for population assistance. 1.11 The major organizations that constitute the private channel include the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF), Family Planning International Assistance (FPIA), Pathfinder Fund, the Association for Voluntary Sterilization (AVS), and the Population Council. IPPF is actually a loose worldwide federation of indigenous private family planning associations in over 100 nations. (Even China has an affiliation with IPPF, through a parastatal organization.) The developing countries' family planning associations spend roughly $90 million annually on efforts to establish family planning services, information, and supportive public policy. They raise over one-third of their funds, from sales of contracep- tives and services, from their own governments, from private donations, etc. Most of the rest (almost $50 million) comes from contributions o.- official development assistance to IPPF headquarters, which then makes grants to the FPAs. Some 25 countries contribute official population assistance to IPPF, collectively over one-third of what they contribute to UNFPA. The leading donors are the United States, Japan, Sweden, United Kingdom, and Norway. FPIA is a branch of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America (the U.S. IPPF affiliate). It works with private organizations and governments in developing countries to introduce family planning in innovative ways and often in difficult circumstances. Its annual program, recently about $16 million, is funded largely by the United States. It is most active in Bangladesh, Brazil, Mexico, the Philippines, and Thailand. Functional Categories of Population Assistance 1.19 Population assistance is traditionally divided into several broad (and sometimes overlapping) categories: -- family planning services is the principal category, accounting for about two-thirds of population assistance. It comprises technical advice on design and management of family planning programs, provision of contraceptives and related medical equipment, training for personnel (or more usually for trainers of personnel), and financial support for actual operations and evaluations. Sometimes "closely related" maternal and child health services or health infrastructure is included, with no unanimity on where to draw the line. Related research is also included; -- information, education and communication (IEC) to build support for family planning and interest in population issues among the public and its leaders and to inform family planning users about child-spacing (links to health, possible methods, etc.); -- demographic analysis including basic data collection and "population dynamics" analyzing demographic trends; -- policy analysis, covering efforts to develop and implement policies affecting population (thus including some social science research that may relate to operations research); -- broader special or "multisectoral efforts". 1.20 UNFPA estimates that roughly two-thirds of population assistance worldwide goes for family planning programs and "related" health measures, about one-fifth for official development assistance policy development and related demographics, over one-tenth for "multisector" activities, and only 5% for IEC and special programs (1981 expenditure data). (See Table 1.7, which uses the "broad definition" of assistance including World Bank and Ford and Rockefeller as well as ODA.) Over the past decade, family planning (and related health services) have accounted for two-thirds to three-fourths of the total. Demographic data collection and analysis accounted for a higher share several years ago (when first censuses and related efforts were getting underway in Africa and elsewhere). Why countries request various types of assistance and trends in actual assistance are discussed in Chapter III.

 - 25 - CiAPTER II RATIONALES F'OR POPULATION ASSISTANCE 2.01 Support for development assistance of any kind is limited in many donor countries, including some that nonetheless provide the bulk of assistance today. Population assistance, which goes largely to "population programs" that extend family planning in the third world, is sometimes especially controversial. This reflects not only skepticism about foreign aid, but disagreement about the need for lower birth rates and about family planning itself in some donor nations. While population assistance is increasingly considered effective and family planning has generally grown more acceptable in donor nations over the past decade, controversy persists. Controversy is particularly strong now in the United States, long the leading donor. In the Nordic countries, however, population assistance commands stronger support.l/ 2.02 Some advocates of population assistance believe the very future of the world, the preservation of its resources and natural endowment, and any hope of its now poverty-stricken peoples to achieve decent living standards depend on success in curbing population growth. Some critics deny even the existence of a significant "world population problem" or believe that development will nonetheless occur (at least if economic policies are sound) and naturally create demand for smaller families without specially directed "population programs." Other critics suspect such programs of coercive and unsafe impositions on unsuspecting peoples. Finally, outright opponents regard some family planning methods spread through population programs as immoral. 2.03 These are polar views, of course, but they evoke the deepest issues associated with population assistance. Actually, those same issues arise in both recipient and donor countries, differing only in level of emphasis and concern from one country to another in either category. Family Planning Outreach 3.14 As clinic-based programs become more widely accepted, family planning activists--in donor governments, channel organizations, and the developing countries--usually press to bring services closer to more people to reduce the financial, physical, and psychological cost of obtaining services. But soon demand arises for more sources of service and information within the community itself. This leads to the next major stage of service programs: "outreach" down and out into the community, the ultimate form of which is "community based distri- bution " sometimes including commercial dist,ribution of contraceptives. Over the past several years donors and channel organizations have become convinced of the merits of the outreach approach; USAID, IPPF, FPIA, and Pathfinder now give it top priority, with IPPF leading the way several years ago. UNFPA also welcomes opportunities to assist outreach programs. 3.15 The key to outreach is provision of service through a hierar- chical structure rooted in communities. Family planning information and contraceptives are offered by networks of paramedical "outreach workers" drawn from the communities they serve. These outreach workers are selected from trusted members of the community, often women; they are given brief training (weeks at most). They work on a volunteer basis or for very little compensation, their rewards being largely personal and subjective. Their enthusiasm and dedication are often obvious immediately to the visitor from abroad. Local "community educators", again community leaders such as teachers or priests, may work alongside the outreach workers. AFRICA AND THE NEAR EAST 3.55 Population in Africa is growing faster than in any other region-- 2.7% p.a. on average, 3.5%-4% in several countries including Nigeria, Kenya, and Zambia. Birth rates are very high--over 50 in some ar;eas. But death rates have dropped in the wake of initial improvements in nutrition, sanitation, and health care and efforts to control malaria and other parasitic diseases. (Even so, maternal and child health remains the
 - 65 - poorest of any major region. The infant mortality rate averages 155-160). Family size (TFR) averages about 6.5 children. The picture in the Near East is roughly similar. 3.56 The implications of rapid population growth and high fertility in Africa vary and are not yet always fully understood. Africa is the poorest major region; economies are largely agricultural, but food supplies are inadequate and have actually fallen in per capita terms for several years. The explanations for these food problems are complex, and the extent and role of "population pressure" varies. In some countries no immediate shortage of arable land exists, Elsewhere, although much land appears vacant or underused, carrying capacity may be constrained by aridity or presence of intractable disease. In some countries supplies of practically usable arable land have dwindled to the point where population pressure cannot be ignored--in Kenya land fragmentation and disputes over control of land are major problems worsening rapidly in face of a population now doubling every seventeen years. (Yet children serve key economic and social functions, of course.) Thus, differences in fact, compounded by differences in perception, exist on the extent of "population pressure". Hope persists that investments in irrigation, new crops, fertilizers, etc., to make existing land more productive and further technical change will ward off any real crisis, 3.57 Nonetheless, donors and channels are increasingly concerned at the health and development implications of high fertility in Africa; this concern is increasingly shared, though still generally limited in the region. Several governments are dismayed at the sheer size of projected populations that will require productive jobs, basic education, health care, and, of course, food. Some, including Botswana, the Gambia, Ghana, Kenya, Mauritius, Senegal, the Seychelles, and Swaziland, have adopted population policies aimed at bringing population growth into line with development capacity and objectives. Egypt has long been concerned, along with Tunisia and Morocco. 3.58 Many African and Near Eastern countries lack even rudimentary demographic information and are anxious to understand their situations, and they have requested assistance in demography and policy areas particularly from UNFPA. Dozens of such countries are now completing first censuses or establishing vital registration systems with UNFPA help. 3.59 Moreover, many African countries share particularly severe maternal and child health problems that delaying pregnancy and spacing births can affect. Early and continuous childbearing increases the odds of maternal depletion and infant weakness especially where food and health care are scarce, as it is in Africa. The adverse impact on maternal and child health of too many and too frequent pregnancies is apparent. Yet the number of prenancies per woman may be rising, reflecting weakening of traditional values and traditional child spacing techniques (such as post-partum abstinence) during the process of modernization. Strong pronatalist tradition, perhaps reflecting even higher child mortality in times past, persists. Nonetheless, many countries (including Ethiopia, Lesotho, Nigeria, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda and Zambia) support family planning for reasons of health and family welfare if not explicitly as a means of facilitating broader development progress. The World Bank also fits into the pattern. No precise division of labor has emerged, since developing country conditions vary widely and each "channel" may be asked to cover a range of activities in a given country. Moreover, coordinating multi-donor efforts can be difficult if one's activity depends in a practical way on another's. Nonetheless a rough pattern can be discerned.l/ 4.02 UNFPA primarily assists governments. It is a core source of support for primary health care and family planning programs, for information programs in and out of school, and for demographic data and policy development. It covers the broadest range of needs and has comparative advantage in "start-up" efforts where population remains a sensitive issue. 4.03 The private organizations are the "pathfinders", the innovators who test the political winds, show that well designed family planning services will be welcomed, and improve family planning methods. They work largely with private organizations in the third world but sometimes assist governments. 4.04 USAID's bilateral assistance goes not only to other governments, but also to universities, research institutions, and other private firms working in population. USAID also provides core support for government primary health care and family planning programs, for which it is a princi- pal source of contraceptives (and the main source of pills). When possible it concentrates on the interface between service provider and client, extending and improving outreach. It also supports biomedical and opera- tions research heavily and assists with specialized training, policy development, and analytic demography. 4.05 The World Bank has led in multi-donor efforts to support the extension of major primary health care and family planning programs. It has tended to include construction of clinics and provision of other infrastructure in its own contribution, but assists with training, management advice, and other service-related areas. It also covers population in policy dialogue and supports related analysis and research. 4.06 Other nations' bilateral assistance goes primarily to government PHC and family planning projects, often in cooperation with the World Bank, which may help arrange multi-donor efforts. It responds to developing countries' needs flexibly and sensitively, and it exercises worldwide leadership in building interest in population issues and in establishing policies and programs to deal with those issues. B. The Major Private Organizations 4.39 The major private channels for official population assistance are the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF), Family Planning International Assistance (FPIA), Pathfinder Fund, and Association for Voluntary Sterilization (AVS). Their total annual program level is almost $130 million--IPPF at about $90 million, FPIA at about $20 million, Pathfinder at about $7 million, and AVS at about $10 million. The United States provides about $50 million (almost all of FPIA, Pathfinder, and AVS funding). The developing countries themselves contribute around $40 million (largely to IPPF) and much more in time and resources-in-kind. Several other organizations are also active in population, largely in research, technical assistance, or small-scale programs, including Ford and Rockefeller Foundations with a combined program level of about $8 million, and the Population Council at about $15 million. (Ford and Rockefeller receive no ODA; the Population Council receives some).
 86 4.40 The private organizations have collectively worked to push the family planning frontiers out--by helping establish policles that reflect population issues and that support family planning, by initiating and extending safe, effective, affordable, and acceptable family planning services, and by promoting public understanding of family planning and population. They provide continuity even during political upheaval and often set standards for cost-effectiveness0 They work with a wide range of public and private institutions. 4.41 Private organizations efforts are part and parcel of developing countries' own efforts to extend serviLces and informationo Often LDC governments explicitly ask their family plannlng association (FPA) to help initiate family planning services wlthin a government primary health care program, or to cover a hard-to-reach Tegion or group of people, or intro- duce a new family planning method, or provide education and information in conjunction with government primary health care. Governments also look to FPIA or Pathfinder to assist similarly, w^sorking through indigenous organi- zations (sometimes the FPA)O Often--perhaps typically--governments look to the private organizations and their deve1oping-country partner organiza- tions for guidance in designing broader family planning programs0 Govern- ments and, at their request, UNFPA and the World Bank have frequently taken over and built upon the foundations laid by private organizations0 4.42 While the private organizations continue to establish supportive policies, get services started, and build public support for family plan- ning, their major impact recently has been on delivery of family planning services: showing that vigorous outreach can work better than passive clinic-based services; introducing voluntary sterilization; and designing creative approaches for reaching the hard-to-reach, often involving inte- gration of family planning into other development efforts or community activities0 4A43 IPPF, FPIA, and Pathfinder--often working together-have tested and expanded major outreach programs relying on outreach or "community based distribution" (CBD) of one form or another0 Such programs vary by culture, geography, and economy, but typically involve networks of volun- teer or nominally paid outreach workers linked into a public or private health system and covering anywhere from a few hundred to several million people0 Estimating cost and impact is, of course, hazardous, but the private organizations believe these programs usually cost no more than a few dollars per active user per annum ($2-7), or something around $o50-2000 per capita population depending on composition services, number of users, population density, terrain, etc0 (This assumes pre-existlng clinics and sometimes free contraceptives0) And they typically lead to comparatively high "prevalence" of contraception--over 50% of couples of reproductive age in many difficult areas including Bangladesh, Brazil's Wortheast, and rural Colombia0 Prevalance rates of 15-20% are also reported in some pilot programs in Kenya and Sudan0 These programs are too small to have national demographic impact except in Colombia, Brazil, arguably Mexico and Bangladesh and Indonesia, and several smaller countrieso RepAlcability-' --management, financing, logistics---may not be easy or simple0 But key elements of programs design involving outreach are finding their way Into national programs0
 - 87 - 4.44 The Association for Voluntary Sterilization leads the way in providing safe and affordable sterilization, particularly through outpa- tient techniques--vasectomy with local anesthesia and minilaparotomy or, where conditions permit, laparoscopy. (Minilaparotomy with local anaesthe- sia is often the technique of choice for female sterilization in developing country conditions). FPAs have also initiated such programs, and Path- finder and FPIA also support extension of sterilization. In a few coun- tries, notably India and Bangladesh, governments are beginning to extend voluntary sterilization programs, often looking to private organizations' experience for guidance or technology, informed consent, and management. The Bangladesh Association for Voluntary Sterilization, an affiliate of the international AVS, accounts for about one fifth of Bangladesh's sterilization acceptors. 4.45 The Population Council has supported extensive biomedical, operations, and policy-related research and policy development efforts. It has helped establish family planning particularly in Thailand and the Philippines. 4.46 While the private organizations have worked to develop family planning services that governments would take over, in Latin America pri- vate programs provide much of subsidized family planning for the poor. The two largest national family planning associations, Colombia's PROFAMILIA and Brazil's BEMFAM, have both pioneered service delivery on a broad scale. Honduras, Guatemala, and Mexico also have major private programs (Mexico's involving not only the FPA but a number of other indigenous private organizations). In Bangladesh private organizations have been asked to focus on urban areas and together provide significant coverage, particularly through community-based outreach. In Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines, private programs--in cooperation with government efforts-- have also made a demographic difference. Even here, however, every private organizations work for government support of "regular" family planning so that they are freer to do what they do best--innovate. 1. IPPF 4.47 Founded thirty years ago in India, IPPF is an international federation of over 100 indigenous national family planning associations, or FPAs--largely volunteer organizations with links to national leadersip and the broader community. IPPF's 1983 program is about $90 million. IPPF receives over half of its funds in contributions of official development assistance (about $49 million in 1983) largely from a dozen OECD nations including the United States ($12 million), West Germany, Japan, the Nordic countries, and Canada. It receives smaller amounts from UNFPA and from some of the wealthier FPAs and other sources. About a third (roughly $34 million in 1983) is raised by the FPAs in developing countries often from their own government, from sales of contraceptives, occasionally from bilateral USAID or other sources. (See Table 4.11.) IPPF programs directly serve some 5 million acceptors at an average cost of roughly $2.00 per user per year (ranging from under $1.00 in the Indian Ocean area to about $2.60 in the Western Hemisphere, roughly estimated). IPPF indirectly serves some 10 million acceptors. It has a substantial backlog of requests for further assistance.

 - 93 - (a) National Family Planning Associations in Latin America 4.52 Latin America has long been IPPF's leading region. The Western Hemisphere has many outstanding FPAs with substantial programs, including the world's largest private programs--Brazil's BEMFAM, and Colombia's PROFAMILIA. Guatemala's APFROFAM, Honduras's ASHONPLAFA, and Mexico's FEPAC also run major programs. 4.53 Brazil's BEMFAM works to build a broad constituency in support of family planning locally and ultimately within government. It is the principal provider of subsidized family planning for the poor. BEMFAM was established in 1965 by obstetricians and gynecologists alarmed at results of research on abortion. 4.54 While the Federal Government still stops short of supporting family planning, BEMFAM cooperates with State Governments to extend free services through community-based distribution in seven major states, including several in the impoverished Northeast. In 1980 BEMFAM served over 300,000 new acceptors from its 2,000 various service points in most of Brazil's 22 states, but the seven-state outreach program and accounts for 80% of its acceptors. Outreach approaches vary, but a description of the Rio state effort is illustrative. There an outreach program serves some one-million fertile-age women in union, through 180 distribution posts in 64 municipalities (which donated the space). Some 180 distributors and 200 community educations volunteer, backed by supervisory field workers and physicians. Vigorous educational efforts are also underway. Reported annual costs per acceptor (net of contraceptives) are only $3.50--about half the level in other states, reflecting a more urbanized population generally easier to reach.11/ 4.55 BEMFAM is not the sole provider of services. Many women receive family planning services trom private physicians, pharmacies, and traditional health-care priorities. But BEMFAM is the principal source of subsidized services, for the poor. In the three northeastern states where its CBD programs have run for several years, overall contraceptive use far exceeds that in Bahia, where no program exists, or Piaui, where the program is just starting. BEMFAM reports costs per active user (net of contraceptives) $6-9 per annum, less in some urban areas. (Pathfinder and FPIA each provide some assistance to BEMFAM outreach programs as discussed below.) 4.56 Colombia's PROFAMILIA introduced community-based distribution of services; voluntary sterilization; commercial distribution; radio advertising; and local fund raising. It began family planning services by working with the Coffee Growers' Associations, branched out to urban and then rural outreach, and encouraged the Government to extend services, though it still accounts for 40% of available services. PROFAMILIA seeks more cost-effective ways to serve hard to reach groups and areas. In its community-based distribution in both urban and rural areas, it achieved impressive prevalence at a cost of only a few dollars per active user annually (less than $3, net of contraceptives in urban areas). It now 11/ FPIA, Brazil Project Description and Budget, unpublished.

 - 99 - (c) Family Planning Associations in Asia 4.63 In Asia, the national family planning associations work to strengthen official commitment to population policies and family planning programs, build public support, develop better ways of delivering services, and extend services to hard to reach groups and areas. Thus they support the major government programs, choosing their efforts to complement those programs most effectively. 4.64 In Bangladesh, the FPA promotes broader support for family planning, develops effective models for delivering services, especially via outreach in urban areas, develops more effective strategies for reaching youth, promotes private organizations' interest in family planning, and demonstrates replicable integrated projects involving other welfare organizations working especially with youth, women and religious groups. 4.65 In India, the FPA helps increase public understanding of and support for family planning, strengthen government programs of voluntary family planning, test community-based distribution programs, work with other local agencies in integrated projects, and develop the role of volunteer agencies. In its Karnataka Project--covering 300,000 people--the FPAI operated a community-based distribution program that the communities though poor, supported heavily. In the Varanasi Project, the FPIA cooperates with the government primary health centers and Benares University in a pilot primary health care projects for 400,000 people now being extended to the District's 2.8 million rural people. Traditional healers, community health centers, and auxfliary nurses provide the outreach and women are trained in income generating skills. Communities are assuming increasing financial responsibility for this project. Similar integrated community-based projects are underway in several other locations show greater acceptability than normal government programs. 4.66 In Indonesia the FPA pioneers approaches for hard-to-reach groups such as youths and dropouts, provides sterilization (with some AVS assist- ance) in 31 districts, experiments with community-based distribution, and supports a major youth program. In 11 areas it helps raise poor women's status through income generation while providing family planning. 4.67 In Thailand, the FPA builds public support and cooperates with other private organizations to extend service delivery in hard to reach areas including the Northeast (especially the refugee areas). 2. FPIA 4.68 Family Planning International Assistance is an arm of the U.S. IPPF affiliate, established more than a decade ago. Since 1971, it has provided almost $86 million in population assistance. Its annual program, recently about $16 million, serves some 900,000 family planning clients in over 40 countries at a cost averaging roughly $7 per year (higher in Africa) and provides other contraceptives and medical supplies to govern- ments. FPIA is funded largely by USAID. It too has a substantial backlog of projects awaiting funds and could increase its program by half within a year.

 - 102 - 4.69 FPIA helps introduce family planning services and information in innovative ways through non-governmental organizations--church groups and hospitals, women's groups, youth groups, trade unions, etco Sometimes it also assists government programs. FPIA works in tough places--where poverty, geography, culture or politics particularly inhibit family plan- ning. Its efforts, though usually small-scale, often provide real guidance for nascent government programs as official and public attitudes in such places begin to thaw. Indeed FPIA's success helps foster change0 4.70 FPIA's hallmark is the modest program showing that family plan- ning and basic maternal and child health care can be provided through community-based outreach at an affordable cost even in poor areas. But in Mexico, Brazil, the Philippines and a few other places, FPIA's programs have made a demographic difference0 FPIA assists with: -- contraceptive services perhaps with broader health or family welfare services; -- training; -- information and education on family planning and responsible parenthoodo 4.71 About half of FPIA's assistance is for "projects" and about half for "commodities." Its project assistance covers technical advice and a variety of resource needs0 Commodity assistance covers contraceptives, equipment, and other supplies necessary to implement family planning programs0 Much of the commodity assistance goes to government programs requiring no technical or other assistance0 Geographic Distribution of Assistance 4.72 FPIA's leading region ls Latin America, which receives over a third of commodity, project and total resources0 East Asia accounts for about a fourth of total resources (more of commodities), South West Asia about a fifth (and more of commodities), and Africa about 13% of commodity, project, and total resources0 (Interregional programs account for the remaining 5% of project resources0) FPIA's top five countries are Mexico at $19.2 million (22%), Philippines at $9.7 million (11%), Bangladesh at $9.1 million (11%), Thailand at $6.3 million (7%), and Indonesia at $408 million (6%)o Over 1971-1982, these five countries together accounted for about half non-commodity resources, two-thirds of commodity resources, and over half of combined resources0 Brazil also receives substantial project assistance. 4.73 FPIA has shifted toward Africa and away from Asia and inter- regional programs but still respornds to major opportunities in Latin America. In 1981 about 45% of FPIA's total resources went to Latin America and the Caribbean, the largest region since 19780 East Asia ranked second at 20% in 1981, down from its historic level of about 27%. Interestingly Africa ranked third in 1981 at 18%, up sharply from its historic level of
 - 103 - 13%. South West Asia ranked fourth in 1981 at 15%, down slightly from its historic level of 18%. 4.74 Secular non-government organizations generally account for about half of all FPIA projects. But FPIA leads in supporting private religious organizations interested in family planning, though their share of projects has dropped from 38% of all projects ever active to 30% of projects active in June, 1982. Some 15% of its active projects in 1982 were with host country governments, compared to 10% for all projects ever active. About half of FPIA's projects have been based jointly in urban and rural areas, one-fifth primarily in urban (up more recently), and one-third primarily in rural. Ninety percent of its projects focus on family planning services primarily, 7% on information primarily, and 3% on training primarily. Most "family planning" projects offer family planning in conjunction with maternal and child health, and almost all do in Africa. 4.75 FPIA has substantially assisted family planning in Mexico, furnishing contraceptives to the government's rural primary health care program and assisting private urban programs of maternal and child health care and family planning that are now models outside as well as inside Mexico. In Brazil, FPIA is helping the vigorous national family planning association, BEMFAM, establish family planning in the state of Rio. In Indonesia, FPIA is helping bring family planning to the remote outer islands (through an indigenous Muslim organization), to introduce sterilization, and to begin reaching youth more effectively. In Bangladesh, FPIA supports some promising projects, with women's organizations providing family planning door-to-door in the slums of Dacca and Chittagong. In programs areas about a fifth of fertile-age women now practice family planning. Some of FPIA's most intriguing projects are in Africa. In Kenya several outreach programs serving disparate areas now report over a fifth of fertile-age couples practicing family planning; in Liberia FPIA is training family planning workers for a new primary health care program the government is establishing. Such programs are not easy to run and costs are not as low as in Asia or Latin America, raising concerns for replicability. But they do show family planning services will not go unused. 4.76 In Kenya, FPIA has assisted the Chogoria hospital in providing community-based outreach, linked to the health system, in an area of roughly 200,000 people. (Both Sweden and the United Kingdom have also assisted this project.) A system of satellite clinics and distribution posts bring primary health care to within 2.5 miles of every major population center, outstanding coverage for Africa. Communities have built and maintained their own clinics. Outreach workers from the communities visit homes, identify women who wish to practice family planning, and help them obtain services (resupplying pills at home). Over one-fifth of eligible women in the whole area are practicing family planning, the highest level in Kenya. (About 75% choose the pill.) Costs are difficult to estimate for family planning only, since much primary health care is also included. The cost per capita population is roughly $2.00, the cost per family planning user perhaps ten times that--reflecting the greater difficulty of organizing and extending services in Africa and the still limited demand for services. Similar FPIA projects are underway in two in Nigeria and the Sudan.

CWFP started in the 1974 famine and scon became convinced that women of the urban slums needed and wanted fami.y planning but could not get services as their poverty and highly conservative muslim traditions confined them to their one-room homes. But other wyomen, still Muslim but less restricted, could reach out to them0 So, In X976, CUFP began providing house-to-house family planning services (pullb and condoms) and advice and referral for maternal and child health problems, reaching into the poorest slums of Dacca to ten other citieso It serves only 60,000 users, but in the neighborhoods it covers, a substantial fraction of women do want these services. The implied annual cost per active us~er is about $6.00. 3. PATHFINDER 4.78 The Pathfinder Fund, an American foundation established in 1957, encourages highly innovative approaches to foster family planning and ultimately reduce population growtho Since 1970, it has provided almost $63 million in assistance in some 55 countrieso0 Pathfinder's 1981 annual program level was about $4.7 million; the 1982 level was about $7 million0 Pathfinder receives over 80% of its funding from USAID and most of the rest from private sources0 4.79 Pathfinder is particularly known for its willingneso to innovate, its flexibility, and its cooperative spirit0 Usually, Pathfinder makes relatively small grants for "pathfindlng" activities that governments or other major institutions may be leery of trying but willing t:o replicate once tested0 It seeks developing country organizations such as family planning associations, women's organizations, or community groups ready to act but needing help to get started0 Pathfinder, like other private family planning organizations, has had to shelve projects for lack of funds recently. 4080 Pathfinder tries to root actual service delivery in communities so that the broadest layer of service gets managed locally0 It thus strengthens the tradition of "community-based service" that private organizations and a few governments have helped buildo 4.81 Pathfinder's early exploratory efforts helped establish government services and IPPF affiliates in a number of countri°s in Asia, Africa and Latin America0 In 1976, reflecting growing intersot in how development affects family planning practice, Pathfinder bro&dened its efforts0 It now supports projects in three main functional categories. Fertility services, women's programs, and population policy. In 1981/82, of its $4o7 million expenditures in S981/82 allocable by function, over $2.9 million or almost two-thirds went for fertility services.12/ 12/ Private correspondence from the Pathfinder Fund0
 - 105 - Program Activity by Region 4.82 Pathfinder has some 88 projects active at present, including 15 in Africa, 36 in Latin America, 28 in Asia, and 9 non-regional. Pathfinder also makes commodity grants, some 132 recently, including 43 in Africa, 73 in Latin America, and 16 in Asia. Over the past four years its geogra- phical allocations have also fluctuated considerably as Pathfinder has tried particularly to respond to opportunities in Africa and the Middle East, which have developed erratically. On balance about one-fourth of its resources have gone to Africa and the Middle East, about half to Latin America, about one-fifth to Asia, and less than one-tenth to non-regional programmes. 4.83 In Africa Pathfinder's efforts remain modest. Programs are often difficult to organize, and results are limited. But in Kenya, Pathfinder is assisting Maendeleo Ya Wanawake, the largest national women's organiza- tion (with a thirty year history and some 200,000 members from all over Kenya). Maendeleo groups organize grassroots self-help projects to raise income and improve living conditions and is pioneering a family planning education program to reach 960 community leaders and 3000 local groups and community-based family planning program in two communities. Like many organizations in poorer countries, this project has not always run smoothly, but in Kenya as in Mexico or Bangladesh, women are beginning to organize to obtain family planning for themselves. 4.84 In Latin America, Pathfinder has helped establish and extend community-based family planning outreach services for people living in poor and often rural areas, working with several outstanding national family planning associations, women's organizations, drugstores, and other private channels. Several major Pathfinder projects assist national family planning associations in reaching into new areas--generally the poorer or more remote regions lacking other sources of regular service. -- In Brazil, Pathfinder assists BEMFAM's effort to establish services in four of Brazil's impoverished Northeastern States, Pernambuco and Alagoas, Piaui and Ceara. -- In Colombia, Pathfinder has assisted a PROFAMILIA project to extend community-based services in rural areas of seven Colombian Departments. This established program now covers 80% of the population or some 3.2 million people, including about 450,000 women of reproductive age in union.  - 118 - CHAPTER V FUTURE OF POPULATION ASSISTANCE INTRODUCTION 5.01 The future of official development assistance for population depends considerably on donors' assessments of four questions: (1) How! serious is the "population problem" in terms of health, women'a rights, development drag, or environment; (ii) How effective are the approaches to dealing with population growth and high fertility; (iii) How welcome and necessary is foreign assistance; and (iv) How politically sensitive is such assistance at home. 5O2 While many donors believe agree that the "population problem" deserves attention, limitations on political support for any development assistance often keep aid levels down, and controversy over family planning (strong in the United States currently) has helped keep population assistance to no more than 2% of total aid0 If donors think that population assistance is wanted, if they think that no one else will step in to help, and if they think that population assistance wiorks reasonably well, then they may be more inclined to take on the political hazards and increase assistance at least modestly01/ 5.03 As shortages of funds at UNFPA and IPPF suggest, demand for population assistance is high and rising02/ W^hile population assistance may have been sensitive in many countries a decade ago, the tide is turning. Requests for population assistance now exceed available funds by at least 20% conservatively estimated, and several organizations could develop substantially larger portfolios of good projects within a year or so. Over 90% of the people of the third world outside China now live in countries whose governments have requested population assistance, largely to extend family planning. About two-thirds live in countries whose governments are committed to slowing population growth, though interest and progress in doing so varies. The rest live in countries xwhere governments at least support family planning as a health measureo The rising requests for population assistance backed by support from national leaders and by generally extensive use of services where available suggest that population assistance is indeed wanted03/ 1/ USAID (IDCA) "Population/Health :nitiative," Novo 1980; USAID (IDCA) "Commentary on the Brandt Commission: Population," April, 1980, both by this writer when responsible for population and health policy at USAID. 2/ Although some of these projects are not fully developed, miost are, according to these organizations0 3/ Though a view persists that donor governments may have overestimated demand and be pressing recipient governments to take such assistance for broader foreign policy reasonso See, e.g., Simon, Julian and Kasun, Jacqueline.

Data are sketchy, but developing countries generally cover an increasing share of family planning costs themselves. 5.05 Most donors believe developing countries cannot be expected to cover much larger shares of family planning program costs particularly as they are trying to expand family planning and broader PHC systems. Moreover, costs of lean systems arise largely from salaries, transport, and medicines and thus recur, so that one massive effort to raise funds will not solve the problem. However, donors, channels, and developing countries are increasingly exploring ways of "self-financing" these systems by charging something for services (perhaps still with a hefty subsidy as in Bangladesh and Colombia), encouraging communities to help build and maintain clinics (even in Africa) and support outreach workers (by using homes or shops as distribution posts as in Indonesia or Brazil). Moreover, contraceptives and other basic medicines are increasingly channeled through commercial firms (e.g. USAID-supported "social marketing" of pills or condoms in Jamaica and Bangladesh and a massive new proposal from India). And the private sector is beginning to expand without donor involvement in many urban areas where enough people can afford to pay market prices for private health care. For the near term, however, commercial distribution cannot obviate the extension of family planning or assistance to support it. And, especially in poorer countries, government must be the main source of basic health services in many areas where the private sector does not reach. Thus donors' assessments of how well such assistance works and how much assistance will be needed are critical to the future of population assistance and population programs. This chapter considers issues that bear on these two points: - Effectiveness of population assistance programs; - Voluntarism, coercion, and informed consent; - Demand-side effects; - "Leverage"; and - Assessments of future needs A. Effectiveness of Population Assistance Programs 5.06 Since population assistance focuses on family planning and has contributed materially in almost all countries where family planning has been extended widely, the basic question is: what have third world family planning programs accomplished, and how has population assistance helped? Most donors and channel organizations have focused on the impact of family planning on population growth rather than health or other benefits. The Demographic Base 5.07 Most population assistance goes to countries whose official demographic objectives are expressed as reductions in "population growth rates" (rates of natural increase). Since most also seek to reduce mortality, population growth is to be slowed by more than proportional reductions in birth rates, and "progress" is usually measured by birth rate declines. Sometimes efforts are also made to adjust at least roughly for method effectiveness and/or age of users, and occasionally strenuous efforts are made to estimate costs per couple year of protection. A related measure of affordability is cost of service coverage per capita population, which makes it easier to compare to PHC and other health services commonly planned on that basis. 5.40 USAID has probably led among donors in supporting efforts to determine cost-effectiveness through its operations research and other programs, although no donor lacks concern in this area. Clear answers have been frustratingly elusive. Complicating factors include how much "health" is combined with family planning, how much services or commodities are donated by donors or indeed by local communities, and how popular the family planning services prove to be. Within these constraints, all the private organizations and USAID have published some estimates of costs per active user, per new acceptor, or per couple-year-of-protection under their programs. Usually donors and channels simply divide total program costs by reported acceptors ("new" and/or "continuing"). It appears that costs may exceed $20 per active user annually in more difficult settings where volunteer service providers may be few, pre-existing health infrastructure scarce, and management even scarcer, and where culture may require provision of family planning in conjunction with much broader maternal and child health--as in much of Africa. But even in rural Bangladesh, programs can be designed with sufficient appeal and "leanness" to give costs of below $10 per active user. In Latin America, costs of family planning outreach in rural areas fall in the $10-20 range, clinic-based programs closer to $15, and some urban outreach programs under $3 net of contraception. IPPF reports overall cost per user averaging under $2 per year. FPIA reports closer to $7, more in Africa. The Indonesia program reports about $15, perhaps $10 for the family planning portion. All of these cost estimates are very soft. Aside from the conceptual and definitional problems, the measurement problems can be appalling. But they give ballpack notions--costs presently average $10 or $20 per user per year, not $100. 5.41 To the extent that community participation can be increased, costs can be reduced sharply. In some settings, e.g., Bangladesh, most program leaders believe people are too poor to be asked to pay anything for family planning, though even there some experiments are underway in subsidized pricing. In Brazil, BEMFAM argues for free services, while in Colombia, PROFAMLIA charges subsidized prices--and attracts some clients from lower cost or free government programs because of superior service through local outreach. As family planning becomes established, it seems increasingly possible to attract local resources to help defray costs

Informed Consent, Voluntarism, and Coercion 5.48 Given the political sensitivity of population assistance and the widespread concern for voluntarism, the linked issues of voluntarism, coer- cion, and informed consent affect the future of population assistance substantially. They currently arise in three main ways. Safety and Informed Consent 5.49 Since most contraceptives have side effects, concern arises that clients understand the benefits and associated risks and give not only voluntary but also informed consent. (Even some "natural family planning" methods have practical problems.) Critics of family planning fear or believe that unsafe or untested family planning methods may be imposed on poor and uneducated people, women especially.29/ They point to past occa- sions when clients' lack of understanding did apparently lead to misuse of contraceptives and allege that shoddy delivery of services continues with- out enough regard for clients' welfare. Too little effort has gone, they believe, to ensuring consent based on real understanding. Failing this, they argue that family planning programs should be curtailed. Family plan- ning supporters have also endorsed the principle of informed consent. They too know of instances where clients apparently misunderstood and misused methods or ceased practicing family planning altogether. But while sup- porters agree that clients ought to understand the pros and cons of avail- able methods thoroughly, they support programs that do a good--albeit imperfect--job. Basically they consider the dangers of contraception to be often overestimated and the benefits underestimated and argue that the perfect should not be the enemy of the good. They also press for increased attention to "user perspective" via training of outreach workers, informa- tion for clients, and more practical and meaningful guidelines on voluntary consent. 5.50 Particular concern has focused on sterilization since it is generally permanent and few clients are likely to be familiar with it. For example, many men have apparently been discouraged from vasectomy by con- fusing it with castration. Women, on the other hand, need to understand what to expect post-operatively and how to care for themselves (since many go home the same day to care for husbands and children). Thus USAID and AVS, among others, have taken great pains to develop guidelines to ensure voluntary and informed consent for sterilization.30/ With such efforts-- and with increasing numbers of satisfied sterilization clients--concern on sterilization has begun to subside. Or to extend particular kinds of family planning programs? "Leverage" is one of the most politically volatile issues associated with population assist- ance--"coercion on a national scale" is the usual reaction. Yet another view persists that it is "common sense" to encourage attention to popula- tion or foster more effective use of scarce assistance funds. What the Policy Is 5.66 The official policy of every donor nation and channel organiza- tion is that the population policy of recipient nations is and should be up to them--that efforts to press recipient countries to "do more" on the population front would be out of place. Some donor and channel organiza- tions also shy away from any prescriptive advice on particular approaches to family planning or population issues more broadly, though others regard this as an appropriate area for professional exchange of views. Why Donors and Channels Avoid Leverage 5.67 Donor nations and channel organizations all believe efforts at leverage would be--and would be perceived as--inappropriate and undue interference in national, cultural, and personal affairs. In developed countries, governments are generally expected to avoid interfering in citi- zens' private lives, and they are naturally even more loathe to interfere overseas. They generally believe leverage in population matters would raise the spectre of imperialism at its worst--thoughtless imposition of Western value judgments on the very heart of other cultures, racism, and even "genocide". This would in turn generate a political backlash just as programs considered coercive apparently did in India. The backlash could make extension of family planning that much more difficult, not only in the countries where leverage was tried, but where programs might already be doing well, thus killing the goose that lays the golden egg. Donors have therefore rejected the whole idea of leverage on the grounds that it is morally abhorrent to them as well as to the recipient nations. 5.68 The strong feelings and resulting potential for political diffi- culty surrounding "leverage" have inhibited and at times actually prevented much discussion on the underlying question, which goes to the heart of development assistance programs of any kind.

doc.repnme: Official development assistance for population activities : a review
doc.abstracts: This paper traces the sources of assistance for family planning & other "population" programs from developed countries & the flow of assistance through principal "channel" organizations to developing countries. The paper discusses why developing countries seek & why developed countries offer population assistance, focusing on official views of how population growth & high fertility affect economic development, environment, maternal & child health, & women's welfare. It explains why some countries are reluctant to seek or provide more population assistance. It analyzes what population assistance does to extend reliable & affordable family planning services & information & to improve understanding of population growth, its causes, & consequences. It summarizes current population policies & family planning programs in major regions of the Third World & discusses the role of assistance. The paper brings out comparative advantages of principal organizations providing population assistance. Finally, the paper discusses the evolution of "policy issues" affecting population assistance, especially donors' concern for "demand" for family planning, cost-effectiveness of family planning services, safety and voluntarism.
